newsitem.title: USA: GM Chairman Smith takes home $6.2 million in 1996.
newsitem.headline: GM Chairman Smith takes home $6.2 million in 1996.

text.p: General Motors Corp. disclosed Wednesday that Chairman Jack Smith took home $6,164,226 in salary, bonus, stock options and other compensation last year, up 9.3 percent from $5,637,931 a year ago.

Excluding exercised stock options, Smith's 1996 salary, bonus and other compensation of $5,781,875 was about even with the $5,738,976 Ford Motor Co. Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Alex Trotman received last year.
Robert Eaton, chairman and chief executive of Chrysler Corp. the smallest of the Big Three automakers, received $8,185,933 in total compensation in 1996, not including exercised options.
Smith's pay, contained in GM's proxy statement released Wednesday, showed the automaker increased his base salary 16.7 percent to $1,750,000, but trimmed his bonus 8.6 percent to $1,600,000.

As with other top-paid executives, the company's board based Smith's bonus on the company's operating performance last year, thus not penalizing him for work stoppages that cost GM $1.2 billion in lost profits in 1996.

Earlier, GM restructured the bonus formula for its salaried employees so their incentive pay was also not hurt by strikes that slashed GM union profit-sharing checks by more than half to about $300 each.
GM gave Smith $2,310,000 in long-term incentive payouts last year, about the same as $2,300,000 in 1995. Smith exercised options worth $382,351 in 1996; he did not exercise options in 1995.

In addition, Smith received options for 200,000 shares of GM common stock in 1996, up from options for 150,000 shares he received a year ago. The options allow Smith to buy shares at $52.25. GM's stock was trading in the $56.25 range Wednesday. GM said the options have a present-day value of $2.8 million.
With the exception of Hughes Electronics Corp. Chairman Michael Armstrong, bonuses fell for all of GM's top-paid executives.

Harry Pearce, GM's vice chairman, received salary and incentives totaling $2,945,000 and stock options for 101,300 GM shares and 31,400 GMH shares. He also exercised options worth $1,066,782 in 1996. In 1995, Pearce earned $2,850,000 in salary and incentives, and exercised options worth $433,813.
